It doesn't matter what Kuroda said, as central bankers' job is to lie, and it doesnt matter how financial markets responded, as "sell-the-(bullish)-news" is extremely common (witness our S&P rip higher on buy-the-bearish-news after the Fed on Wed), and it doesnt matter what financial journalists call things, as they are journalists whose job it is is to come up w/ a reason for every market move. As for the increase in avg duration for the JGB purchases, the QE effect of that duration extension is actually to strengthen QE, as the duration weighted purchases are now significantly increased, even though the net increase in purchases is not literally increased.  The longer the term for a bond, the more volatile its price movements relative to yield changes (the definition of duration), and the bigger the creditor's commitment for a given nominal amount lent.  In other words, what's scarier when you lend money, when you agree to get repaid tomorrow, or when you agree to get repaid in 10 years?
